source.1a58e96f:
cleaned_trip_data %>% group_by(rider_type)%>%
  summarise(min_trip_length = min(trip_length), median_trip_length = median(trip_length),
            max_trip_length = max(trip_length), mean_trip_length = mean(trip_length))
source.89b02e31:
aggregate(cleaned_trip_data$trip_length ~ cleaned_trip_data$rider_type 
          + cleaned_trip_data$day_of_week + cleaned_trip_data$months, FUN = mean)

source.518ad8a0:
cleaned_trip_data %>% group_by(rideable_type, rider_type) %>% summarise(number_of_trips = n()) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = rideable_type, y= number_of_trips, fill = rider_type)) + geom_col() +
  labs(title = "Demand of Rideable type vs number of trips base on rider types")
source.46fb466b:
cleaned_trip_data %>% count(start_hour, sort = T) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x= start_hour, y = n)) + geom_line(size = 1) + 
  labs(title = "Count of Trips by Hours for Pervious 12 Months", x = "Start Hour of Trips",
       y = "Count of Trips")
source.010bf79f:
cleaned_trip_data %>% 
  group_by(rider_type, day_of_week) %>% summarise(average_trip_length = mean(trip_length)) %>%
                              ggplot(aes(x = day_of_week, y = average_trip_length, fill = rider_type)) + 
  geom_col(width = 1, position = position_dodge(width = 1)) + labs(title = "Average Trip Duration in a Day based on rider type",
                                                                   x = "Day of the Week", y = "Average Trip Duration")
source.c7a040ba:
cleaned_trip_data %>% group_by(rider_type, months) %>% summarise(number_of_trips = n()) %>% arrange(rider_type,months) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = months, y = number_of_trips, fill = rider_type)) + 
  labs(title = "Total number of trips in a month") + geom_col(width = 1, position = position_dodge(width = 1))+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 30))
source.e21f31a5:
cleaned_trip_data %>% group_by(rider_type, day_of_week) %>% summarise(number_of_trips = n()) %>% arrange(rider_type,day_of_week) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = day_of_week, y = number_of_trips, fill = rider_type)) + 
  labs(title = "Total number of trips in a week based on rider type") + geom_col(width = 1, position = position_dodge(width = 1))+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 20))
source.8abf59fe:
cleaned_trip_data %>%
  group_by(rider_type,date) %>%
  summarise(number_of_rides = n(), average_duration = mean(trip_length)) %>%
  arrange(rider_type, date) %>% ggplot(aes(x= date, y= number_of_rides, group = rider_type)) + 
  geom_line(aes(color= rider_type)) + labs(title = "Number of Rides by Ride Date and Rider type", X = "Ride Date", y = "Rider Type")
source.db63e704:
trip_data_by_week <- aggregate(cleaned_trip_data$trip_length ~ cleaned_trip_data$rider_type + 
                                         cleaned_trip_data$day_of_week, FUN = mean)
write.csv(cleaned_trip_data, "Trip Data by Week.csv", row.names = F)
source.67d17753:
trip_data_by_months <- aggregate(cleaned_trip_data$trip_length ~ cleaned_trip_data$rider_type +
                                                + cleaned_trip_data$months, FUN = mean)
write.csv(cleaned_trip_data, "Trip Data by months.csv", row.names = F)

source.021f5190:
## Key Findings

* Member riders constantly use the service throughout the week, when Causal riders are more likely to use the service during the weekends.
* Casual riders seem to have longer rides than member riders.
* For the obvious reason, both types of customers use the bikes most during the summer season and least in winter.
* The demand for the bikes is in peak at evening between 1700 to 1800 hours.
* Docked bikes are the most popular bike among both types of users compared to classic and electric bikes.
source.dbc3273a: ##### According to the visualized data, Docked bikes seemed to be the most popular bike among both casual and member riders. Classic bikes and Electric bikes are popular among the member riders. If electric bikes are more expensive to ride for casual riders then the company can consider reducing the riding cost for non-menber riders to increase the demand for electric bikes at least as a campaign. That can possibly attract causal riders to become a member.

1. Aggregate your data so it’s useful and accessible.
2. Organize and format your data.
3. Perform calculations.
4. Identify trends and relationships.

**Deliverable**

A summary of your analysis
source.86fc4d3d: ##### According to the visualized data, the average trip duration of casual riders seems to be more than double of member riders. That means there are more non-member users than member users. That gives a hint there is a huge amount of non-member users that can be converted as members with proper marketing. The visualization may seem like causal riders are taking longer trips than the member riders which is true to some extent but does not have to possibly be true every time. I could possibly mean there are more casual users than members. The column chart also shows that there are more users during the weekends than on weekdays.

source.8ab70ad1:
##### According to the visualized data, among both types of users bike rides are most popular during the months of summer which is obvious. Then it starts decreasing during the Autumn. The demand is lowes during the Winter season. Then it starts increasing again during the Spring. 

##### If the maintenance cost is expensive, the company can stop their operation during the Winter-time and resume it again from Spring. By that time company can put the resource and effort more into R&D to make the service better.

source.77ce6515:
## Additional data you could lead to more deep and detail analysis

* Age group data: This could be used to understand the customers better and also can be used to stand out different promotional offers, such as off-peak hours offers.
* occupational data: This could create different kinds of membership offers, such as Student members, Career partners members (e.g. private courier services, food delivery services), and General members (that includes every one but Students and courier partners).

source.9cd95cd5:
##### This project will cover all six data analysis stages,
* Ask
* Prepare
* Process
* Analyze
* Share
* Act
source.4eec4993: ### Inspecting the combined data frame that has been created recently by calling list of column name
source.8d7ca283:
##### The first stage "ASK" has 2 key tasks 

1. **Identifying the business task**

    Cyclistic is already a well-known bike-sharing company that is operating for quite a few years now. Right now it has 2 types of users Annual Members and Causal(non-member users). According to financial analysts, the annual members are much more profitable than the causal riders. According to the marketing director Lily Moreno, maximization of the annual membership is key to long-term success. The aim of the task is to design marketing strategies that will convert casual riders to annal members. 
    
2. **Consider key satakeholders**

     The marketing director Lily Moreno, assigned me to identify how these two different types of users use Cyclistic bikes differently. The Cyclistic marketing analytics team is responsible for creating cyclistic marketing strategies by collecting, analyzing, and reporting data. Finally, the marketing executive team will decide whether or not the new marketing strategy will be implemented or not. 
     
   **Deliverable**

       A clear statement of the business task. The business taks is to provide insight to the marketing analyst team by analyzing the Cyclistic historical bike trip data to better understand how annual members and casual riders differ, why casual riders would buy a membership, and how digital media could affect their marketing tactics.

source.71bb2f5b:
##### There are 4 key tasks for the preparation stage. Download data and store it appropriately, Identify how it’s organized, Sort and filter the data, and Determine the credibility of the data. For this project, I have used the publically available data presented by "Motivate International Inc." I have downloaded the latest 12 months Cyclistic bike-sharing Zipped data according to the instruction and up-loaded it into Kaggle under the name of "bike-share capstone project". The latest 12 months data seems to be organized. However, there are some minor changes and missing values which will be identified. From the huge data set, we have already shorted and filtered the latest 12 months' data. Determine the credibility of the data. Data was imported from https://divvy-tripdata.s3.amazonaws.com/index.html which is a credible source. 

**Deliverable**
   
  A description of all data sources used. The monthly .csv files as data (April 2020 to March 2021) has been imported from https://divvy-tripdata.s3.amazonaws.com/index.html.
source.af1275a0:
## Recommendations 

* The company should send out attractive promotions to attract more members.
* Off-peak hours price should be discounted (that may attract younger age group customers more in addition).
* the company can introduce different levels of membership (that can brings benefits like reduced riding or fees) that can be achieved through membership longevity.
